hero.title: Your Personalized Senior Frontend Engineer Roadmap is Ready!

radarAxes.label: Architecture
radarAxes.title: Frontend Architecture
radarAxes.description: Design systems, micro-frontends, component architecture, and frontend platform engineering.

radarAxes.label: Performance
radarAxes.title: Performance & Optimization
radarAxes.description: Core Web Vitals, bundle optimization, runtime performance, and scalability at enterprise level.

radarAxes.label: Accessibility
radarAxes.title: Accessibility Leadership
radarAxes.description: WCAG 2.1 compliance, assistive technology testing, accessibility advocacy and mentoring.

radarAxes.label: Leadership
radarAxes.title: Technical Leadership
radarAxes.description: Mentoring engineers, establishing best practices, driving technical strategy and cross-team collaboration.

radarAxes.label: Platform
radarAxes.title: Platform Engineering
radarAxes.description: Build tools, CI/CD pipelines, developer experience, frontend infrastructure and tooling.

easy: Leverage your senior frontend experience and architecture knowledge
Showcase your design system and component library work
Demonstrate leadership through mentoring and technical decision-making
doable: Build or contribute to an open-source design system
Document your micro-frontend or architecture projects
Prepare system design discussions for senior frontend roles
challenging: Strong portfolio demonstrating architecture and leadership skills
Prepare for deep technical discussions on performance and scalability
Showcase cross-team collaboration and platform engineering work
stretch: Requires proven track record of senior-level frontend impact
Strong emphasis on architectural decisions and trade-offs
Demonstrate ability to mentor and establish engineering best practices

rounds.name: Portfolio & Architecture Review
points: Present your design system or component library work in detail
Discuss architectural decisions, trade-offs, and lessons learned
Explain how you scaled frontend systems and improved developer experience
Demonstrate impact through metrics: performance gains, team velocity, adoption rates

rounds.name: Frontend System Design
points: Design scalable frontend systems: design system, component library, micro-frontend platform
Cover architecture, state management, API design, performance optimization
Discuss accessibility, internationalization, and cross-browser compatibility
Address team collaboration, versioning strategy, and migration planning

rounds.name: Technical Deep Dive
points: Advanced TypeScript patterns and type system design
Performance optimization: bundle size, runtime performance, Core Web Vitals
Deep dive into React internals, rendering optimization, and server components
Discuss build tools, module federation, and frontend infrastructure

rounds.name: Leadership & Collaboration
points: How you've mentored engineers and established best practices
Examples of driving technical strategy and cross-team collaboration
Handling technical debt, migration planning, and organizational change
Code review philosophy, engineering culture, and team scaling

rounds.name: Hiring Manager / Cultural Fit
points: Career switcher story: transition from non-tech to senior frontend engineer
Discussion about leadership philosophy and team building
Why this company and what impact you hope to make
Questions about team structure, engineering culture, and growth opportunities

easy: Keep practicing DSA regularly to stay sharp
Network and seek referrals to improve chances
doable: DSA fundamentals are essential - solve 75+ problems
Master React and modern frontend tooling
Prepare for machine coding rounds with timed practice
challenging: Strong DSA is mandatory - aim for 120+ problems
Deep understanding of React internals and optimization
Referrals significantly improve your chances - start networking
stretch: This requires 6-8 months of focused preparation
DSA mastery is non-negotiable at this level
Consider building more experience before targeting unicorns

rounds.name: Online Assessment
points: 3-4 coding problems ranging from easy to medium difficulty
Focus on JavaScript problem-solving and algorithmic thinking
May include frontend-specific challenges (DOM manipulation, async operations)
Passing score typically 60-70% to proceed to interviews

rounds.name: DSA Round 1
points: 1-2 medium problems on arrays, strings, or hash maps
Expected to arrive at optimal solution with hints
Code on shared editors like CoderPad or HackerRank
Interviewer evaluates problem-solving approach and communication

rounds.name: DSA Round 2 / Frontend Fundamentals
points: Could be another DSA round or deep dive into JavaScript internals
Topics: closures, prototypes, event loop, promises, this keyword
Questions on React: virtual DOM, reconciliation, hooks, performance
Write code to demonstrate concepts (e.g., implement Promise.all)

rounds.name: Machine Coding / UI Round
points: Build a real-world component: search with autocomplete, pagination, filters
Use React or vanilla JavaScript based on company preference
Focus on code organization, reusability, and edge case handling
Bonus points for responsive design and accessibility considerations

rounds.name: Hiring Manager / Bar Raiser
points: Behavioral questions using STAR format (Situation, Task, Action, Result)
Deep dive into your best project - technical decisions and trade-offs
Questions about handling challenges, tight deadlines, and collaboration
Culture fit assessment - research company values beforehand

easy: Focus on HTML, CSS, and JavaScript fundamentals
Practice basic coding problems for aptitude tests
Prepare clear explanations of your projects
doable: Strengthen your core frontend skills - HTML, CSS, JS
Learn React basics and build simple applications
Practice common interview questions and coding basics
challenging: Solid understanding of web fundamentals is essential
Build a few portfolio projects to showcase
Focus on communication and explaining concepts clearly
stretch: Focus on fundamentals over advanced concepts
This should be very achievable with basic preparation

rounds.name: Aptitude & Online Test
points: Quantitative aptitude, logical reasoning, and verbal ability
1-2 easy coding problems (basic loops, conditionals, arrays)
MCQs on HTML, CSS, JavaScript basics
Focus on accuracy over speed - cutoff-based filtering

rounds.name: Technical Interview 1
points: Questions on HTML tags, CSS selectors, and JavaScript syntax
Explain concepts: var vs let vs const, event delegation, box model
Simple coding: reverse a string, find duplicates in array
Project discussion - be ready to explain your contributions clearly

rounds.name: Technical Interview 2
points: Deeper dive into JavaScript: closures, hoisting, callbacks
Basic React questions if it's on your resume: JSX, props, state
May ask to build a simple layout or debug existing code
Focus on fundamentals - breadth over depth

rounds.name: HR Interview
points: Standard questions: strengths, weaknesses, why this company
Career goals and willingness to learn new technologies
Salary expectations (be realistic for fresher roles)
Relocation flexibility and notice period discussion

easy: Maintain strong DSA practice - solve problems regularly
Prepare for frontend system design discussions
Practice behavioral interviews with STAR format
doable: DSA is the primary filter - solve 150+ LeetCode problems
Master React, performance optimization, and web fundamentals
Build impressive portfolio projects with production quality
challenging: DSA mastery is mandatory - aim for 200+ problems (medium/hard)
Deep frontend system design knowledge is expected
Strong referrals are almost essential - network actively
stretch: This is the highest bar - plan for 6+ months of intense prep
DSA at expert level is non-negotiable
Consider building 1-2 years of experience first

rounds.name: Recruiter Screen
points: Initial call to verify your background and interest
Overview of the interview process and timeline
Questions about visa status, location preferences, start date
Opportunity to ask about the team and role expectations

rounds.name: Phone/Online Technical Screen
points: 1-2 coding problems on shared editor (CoderPad, Google Docs)
Medium difficulty - arrays, strings, hash maps, or trees
Focus on clean code, edge cases, and optimal time complexity
Strong communication is essential - think out loud throughout

rounds.name: Onsite: Coding Round 1
points: Medium to hard DSA problem with live whiteboard or code editor
Common topics: dynamic programming, trees, graphs, recursion
Interviewer evaluates problem breakdown and optimization
Expect follow-up questions to extend or modify your solution

rounds.name: Onsite: Coding Round 2
points: Another DSA problem, potentially harder or different domain
May involve advanced data structures or complex logic
Write clean, bug-free code under time pressure
Discuss multiple approaches before settling on implementation

rounds.name: Onsite: Frontend System Design
points: Design a frontend system: autocomplete, infinite scroll, feed
Cover component architecture, state management, API design
Discuss performance: lazy loading, code splitting, caching
Address accessibility, error handling, and edge cases

rounds.name: Onsite: Behavioral / Googleyness
points: Amazon: Leadership Principles with STAR format
Google: Googleyness - collaboration, growth mindset, adaptability
Prepare stories about ownership, conflict, learning from failure
Questions like 'Tell me about a time you had to learn something new quickly'

rounds.name: Hiring Committee & Team Match
points: Google: Packet reviewed by hiring committee for final decision
Amazon: Bar raiser provides independent assessment
Team matching calls to find mutual fit
Process can take 2-4 weeks post-onsite

phases.title: Advanced Architecture & Design Systems

whatYouLearn.title: Enterprise Design Systems
whatYouLearn.description: Build scalable design systems with design tokens, component API design, versioning strategy, and multi-brand theming

whatYouLearn.title: Micro-Frontend Architecture
whatYouLearn.description: Module Federation, runtime integration, independent deployments, shared dependencies, and cross-team coordination

whatYouLearn.title: TypeScript Architecture Patterns
whatYouLearn.description: Advanced type systems, generics, conditional types, decorators, and type-safe API design for large-scale applications

phases.target: Design and implement scalable frontend architecture used across organization
whyItMatters: Senior engineers drive architectural decisions for entire frontend teams
Design systems reduce development time by 30-50% and ensure consistency
Micro-frontends enable team autonomy and independent deployments at scale

phases.title: Performance & Accessibility Leadership

whatYouLearn.title: Performance at Scale
whatYouLearn.description: Core Web Vitals optimization (LCP < 2.5s, INP < 200ms, CLS < 0.1), runtime performance monitoring, bundle optimization strategies

whatYouLearn.title: WCAG 2.1 Compliance & Advocacy
whatYouLearn.description: Level AA/AAA standards, assistive technology testing (NVDA, JAWS, VoiceOver), accessibility automation, team education

whatYouLearn.title: Performance Profiling & Debugging
whatYouLearn.description: Chrome DevTools advanced usage, React profiler, bundle analysis, memory leak detection, and performance regression testing

phases.target: Drive organization-wide performance and accessibility initiatives
whyItMatters: Performance directly impacts business metrics: 1s delay = 7% conversion loss
Accessibility is mandatory for compliance and reaches 15% more users
Senior engineers set standards and mentor teams on these critical areas

phases.title: Frontend Platform Engineering

whatYouLearn.title: Build Systems & Tooling
whatYouLearn.description: Webpack/Vite optimization, custom build plugins, monorepo management (Nx, Turborepo), CI/CD pipeline configuration

whatYouLearn.title: Developer Experience (DX)
whatYouLearn.description: Code generation tools, CLI development, Storybook automation, testing infrastructure, and developer documentation

whatYouLearn.title: Frontend Infrastructure
whatYouLearn.description: CDN configuration, edge computing, serverless functions, deployment strategies, feature flags, and monitoring systems

phases.target: Build and maintain frontend platform that powers entire engineering organization
whyItMatters: Platform engineering reduces build times by 50-70% and improves team velocity
Good DX attracts and retains top engineering talent
Senior engineers establish infrastructure that enables team scaling

phases.title: Technical Leadership & Organizational Impact

whatYouLearn.title: Mentoring & Technical Leadership
whatYouLearn.description: Code review best practices, 1:1 mentoring frameworks, technical writing, RFC processes, and knowledge sharing systems

whatYouLearn.title: Technical Strategy & Roadmapping
whatYouLearn.description: Architecture decision records (ADRs), migration planning, technical debt management, and cross-functional collaboration

whatYouLearn.title: Senior Interview Preparation
whatYouLearn.description: Frontend system design mastery, portfolio presentation, leadership stories (STAR format), and compensation negotiation

phases.target: Lead frontend initiatives and mentor engineers while excelling in senior interviews
whyItMatters: Senior roles require both technical depth and leadership breadth
Effective mentoring multiplies your impact across the organization
Strong interview skills unlock ₹50-150 LPA opportunities at top companies

projects.title: Enterprise Design System & Component Library
projects.description: Build a production-grade design system with 20+ components, design tokens, Storybook documentation, TypeScript, and accessibility compliance
projects.shortDescription: Scalable design system with component library and documentation
projects.fullDescription: Create a comprehensive enterprise design system that can be used across multiple products. Build a component library with atomic design principles, implement design tokens for theming, write comprehensive TypeScript types, ensure WCAG 2.1 Level AA compliance, and document everything in Storybook. This project demonstrates architecture, API design, accessibility leadership, and platform thinking - core senior-level skills.

implementationSteps.title: Architecture & Foundation Setup
implementationSteps.description: Set up a monorepo with Nx or Turborepo. Create packages: @yourds/tokens (design tokens), @yourds/components (React components), @yourds/docs (Storybook). Define design tokens using Style Dictionary: colors, typography, spacing, shadows, breakpoints. Implement atomic design structure: atoms, molecules, organisms. Set up TypeScript with strict mode and ESLint with accessibility rules.

implementationSteps.title: Core Component Development (Atoms & Molecules)
implementationSteps.description: Build foundational components with compound component patterns: Button (variants, sizes, icons, loading states), Input (text, password, search, validation), Select, Checkbox, Radio, Switch, Badge, Avatar, Icon. Use TypeScript generics for flexible APIs. Implement polymorphic component pattern ('as' prop). Ensure all components are keyboard accessible and screen reader friendly. Write comprehensive prop documentation.

implementationSteps.title: Complex Components & Accessibility (Organisms)
implementationSteps.description: Build advanced components: Modal (focus trap, scroll lock, ESC to close), Dropdown Menu (keyboard navigation, ARIA roles), Tabs (roving tabindex), Tooltip (ARIA-describedby), Toast/Notification system, DatePicker, Autocomplete. Implement ARIA patterns correctly: roles, states, properties. Test with NVDA, JAWS, and VoiceOver. Add focus management and keyboard shortcuts. Use React Context for component composition.

implementationSteps.title: Theming, Dark Mode & Responsive Design
implementationSteps.description: Implement CSS-in-JS theming with emotion or styled-components. Support multiple themes: light, dark, high-contrast. Use CSS custom properties for runtime theme switching. Implement responsive utilities and breakpoint system. Create theme provider with TypeScript types. Support system preference detection (prefers-color-scheme). Build theme switcher component. Ensure all components work across themes with proper contrast ratios (WCAG AAA).

implementationSteps.title: Storybook Documentation & Developer Experience
implementationSteps.description: Set up Storybook 7+ with MDX documentation. Write comprehensive stories for each component: default, all variants, interactive examples, accessibility demos. Add Storybook addons: a11y (accessibility testing), controls (live props editing), docs (auto-generated docs). Create getting-started guides, contribution guidelines, and design principles pages. Implement visual regression testing with Chromatic. Add code snippets and live examples.

implementationSteps.title: Testing, Performance & Publishing
implementationSteps.description: Write unit tests with Jest and React Testing Library (80%+ coverage). Add integration tests for complex component interactions. Implement accessibility testing with jest-axe. Set up bundle size monitoring (bundlephobia). Optimize with tree-shaking and code splitting. Configure rollup/tsup for optimal builds. Publish to NPM with semantic versioning. Set up CI/CD with GitHub Actions: lint, test, build, publish. Create changelog and migration guides. Deploy Storybook to Vercel/Netlify.

projects.title: Micro-Frontend Platform with Module Federation
projects.description: Build a scalable micro-frontend architecture with Webpack Module Federation, shell application, independent deployments, and shared state
projects.shortDescription: Micro-frontend platform enabling team autonomy and independent deployments
projects.fullDescription: Create a production-ready micro-frontend platform that enables multiple teams to work independently. Build a shell application that orchestrates remote micro-frontends, implement shared state management, handle authentication across apps, enable independent deployments, and establish inter-app communication. This project demonstrates advanced architecture, platform engineering, and organizational scaling - essential senior-level competencies.

implementationSteps.title: Platform Architecture & Shell App
implementationSteps.description: Design micro-frontend architecture: shell (host), 3 remote apps (dashboard, settings, analytics). Set up monorepo with separate apps. Configure Webpack 5 Module Federation: define remotes, shared dependencies (React, React-DOM, design system). Build shell application with routing (React Router), navigation, authentication wrapper. Implement dynamic remote loading with error boundaries and fallback UI. Set up TypeScript with shared types package.

implementationSteps.title: Remote Micro-Frontends Development
implementationSteps.description: Build 3 independent remote applications with separate package.json and CI/CD. Configure each as Module Federation remote: expose components/pages. Dashboard: data visualization, charts (Recharts). Settings: user preferences, form handling. Analytics: performance metrics, tables. Ensure each app can run standalone for local development. Implement HMR and fast refresh. Add health check endpoints for shell to verify remote availability.

implementationSteps.title: Shared State & Authentication
implementationSteps.description: Implement shared state management across micro-frontends using Zustand or Redux with Module Federation. Create auth module in shell: JWT token management, refresh logic, role-based access control (RBAC). Share auth state with remotes via Context or shared store. Handle authentication flows: login, logout, token expiry, redirect. Implement route guards in shell and remotes. Add user profile API integration. Ensure security: CSRF protection, secure token storage.

implementationSteps.title: Inter-App Communication & Event Bus
implementationSteps.description: Build custom event bus for cross-app communication: publish/subscribe pattern. Implement use cases: notification system (dashboard → shell → settings), shared data updates, navigation events. Use CustomEvents API or create typed event system with TypeScript. Handle event cleanup to prevent memory leaks. Add debugging tools for event tracking. Implement event replay for late-subscribing remotes. Document communication contracts in shared types.

implementationSteps.title: Independent Deployments & CI/CD
implementationSteps.description: Set up independent CI/CD pipelines for each micro-frontend using GitHub Actions. Shell: build, test, deploy to Vercel/Netlify. Remotes: build, test, deploy to separate S3/CDN with versioning. Implement versioning strategy: semver for remotes, runtime version resolution in shell. Add deployment smoke tests. Configure environment variables per app. Implement rollback mechanism. Set up monitoring for remote failures. Add feature flags for gradual rollouts.

implementationSteps.title: Performance, Monitoring & Developer Experience
implementationSteps.description: Optimize shared dependencies: single React instance, code splitting, lazy loading remotes. Implement performance monitoring: track remote load times, error rates, user interactions. Add error tracking with Sentry across all apps. Create developer documentation: architecture diagrams, setup guides, debugging tips. Build CLI tool for scaffolding new remotes. Add local development mode with mocked remotes. Implement E2E tests with Playwright across shell and remotes. Deploy comprehensive demo with monitoring dashboard.

projects.title: Frontend Performance Monitoring & Optimization Platform
projects.description: Build a performance monitoring platform that tracks Core Web Vitals, provides actionable insights, and automates performance regression detection
projects.shortDescription: Performance platform with Real User Monitoring, Core Web Vitals tracking, and automated alerts
projects.fullDescription: Create a production-ready performance monitoring platform that helps teams track and improve frontend performance. Implement Real User Monitoring (RUM) to capture Core Web Vitals, build analytics dashboard with trends and insights, integrate bundle analysis, automate performance regression detection in CI/CD, and provide actionable recommendations. This project demonstrates performance engineering, data visualization, platform tooling, and organizational impact - key senior engineering competencies.

implementationSteps.title: RUM SDK & Core Web Vitals Collection
implementationSteps.description: Build lightweight RUM SDK (< 5KB gzipped) using web-vitals library. Capture Core Web Vitals: LCP (Largest Contentful Paint), INP (Interaction to Next Paint), CLS (Cumulative Layout Shift), FCP, TTFB. Add custom metrics: route change timing, API response times, component render duration. Use PerformanceObserver API for efficient metric collection. Implement batching and beacon API for data transmission. Add user context: device type, browser, connection speed, geographic location.

implementationSteps.title: Backend API & Data Storage
implementationSteps.description: Build Node.js backend (Express/Fastify) to receive performance metrics. Design database schema (PostgreSQL) for storing: metrics (time-series), sessions, pages, user_agents. Implement data aggregation: p50, p75, p95, p99 percentiles over time. Create API endpoints: ingest metrics, query aggregated data, get trends, compare time periods. Add authentication with API keys. Implement rate limiting to prevent abuse. Set up data retention policy (90 days raw, 1 year aggregated).

implementationSteps.title: Analytics Dashboard & Visualizations
implementationSteps.description: Build Next.js dashboard with React + Recharts/D3.js for visualizations. Overview page: Core Web Vitals score cards, pass/fail indicators (Google thresholds), trend charts (7d, 30d, 90d). Detailed pages: per-page performance, user segmentation (device, browser, geography), session replay links. Implement filters: date range, page, user segment. Add comparison mode: A/B testing, before/after deployments. Create performance score calculation algorithm. Implement drill-down capabilities: click metric to see individual sessions.

implementationSteps.title: Bundle Analysis & Dependency Tracking
implementationSteps.description: Integrate webpack-bundle-analyzer and source-map-explorer. Build bundle analysis API: upload source maps post-build, parse and store bundle composition (packages, sizes, dependencies). Create bundle dashboard: tree map visualization, largest dependencies, duplicate packages detection. Track bundle size over time with alerts for regressions. Implement dependency audit: identify outdated packages, security vulnerabilities, unused dependencies. Generate optimization recommendations: code splitting opportunities, tree-shaking wins.

implementationSteps.title: CI/CD Integration & Performance Budgets
implementationSteps.description: Create GitHub Action for automated performance testing. Run Lighthouse CI on every PR: desktop and mobile tests, multiple pages, multiple runs for consistency. Implement performance budgets: LCP < 2.5s, INP < 200ms, CLS < 0.1, bundle size < 200KB. Fail CI if budgets exceeded with detailed report. Add PR comments with performance comparison: before/after, passed/failed metrics, actionable recommendations. Integrate with bundle analysis: fail if bundle grew > 5% without justification. Add manual override for intentional regressions.

implementationSteps.title: Alerting, Reporting & Developer Tools
implementationSteps.description: Implement alerting system: email/Slack notifications for performance degradations. Define alert conditions: Core Web Vitals exceed thresholds, bundle size spikes, error rate increases. Create weekly performance reports: executive summary, trends, wins, areas for improvement. Build browser extension for real-time performance debugging: overlay showing current page's metrics, comparison to averages, waterfall view. Add performance profiling tools: React component render times, expensive re-renders detection. Deploy platform and integrate with sample application to demonstrate value.
